answers.answer: for the doc's office to call you 3 times MEANS TO ME, its pretty important to get in there.  Diabetic symptoms arent something that should be ignored, irreversable damage can occur with high blood sugar levels over time.  Here are a couple links that explain a lot about it.  You can get treated with insulin or the pills for the next 8 weeks to bring your sugars down to a more normal level.  I dont know how high you are running but they must think its important to get further checking done.  I dont know if tx has been blamed for causing high blood sugars and Im sure you dont want to quit it at this point, so good luck to you!!  I would think either you have diabetes or you dont, but this would be a good question for Erin to answer.  Here's the links:http://www.joslin.harvard.edu/education/library/whigh.shtmlhttp://www.diabetes-symptoms-resource.com/high-blood-sugar.htm

You should listen to your doctor who is talking to you about diabetis and get your numbers check real good and see what is there.  You can do all the proper preparation if you indeed show to have diabetis. This is something that you need to give top priority with, including finishing your treatment.You are so close to the finish line!

UN-treated diabetes not allowed with treatment*, so your options are to look into this diabetes thing right now while on treatment, or stop treatment right now to look into the diabetes.Work up and treatment for your diabetes (most likely oral blood sugar control agents) can easily be done now and your sugars under better control in the next few weeks.  A few months after treatment, the testing can be re-done to see if it was indeed a treatment related thing or just bad timing.In my experience, treatment seems to unmask diabetes and thyroid disease which may have been just below detectable before treatment.GI.PA*Untreated or unknown diabetes can escalate on treatment causing life treatening diabetes issues (diabetic coma..ect).  Fortunately the most common metabolic panel ordered on the liver also contains a glucose..an ok screen for diabetes.

You are past the critical week 12 goal, so the dosage of Peg is thought not to be as important as the Rib dose.Your platelet count is decreased because of the Peg, not the Rib.  The FDA way of doing it is reduce the Peg when platlets hit 80 for Peg Intron (50 for Pegasys).  Discontinue when platlets hit 50  for Peg Intron and 25 for Pegasys (The difference represents the fact that Pegasys came out later and by then we were a little more comfortable with the platlet issue).They are most likely reducing your Rib because of the anemia.  Getting a full dose of Rib as long as possible is most likely more important than a full dose of Peg after week 12.  If your doctor is on-board with Procrit,this is the key time to be getting started on it with hopes of getting you back up to full Rib dose ASAP.The platlet thing is a comfort-level thing.  Most docs get concerned not because you are likely to have a giant bleed with platlets between 50-75, just that if you do, and they havent reduced dose per the package insert, there is a liabilty issue.  Talk to your GI, express concern for the platlets but your concern for SVR is treatment is pulled.  Clearly have him go through the risk of low platlets and the red flags to suggest bleeding problem.  Perhaps acceptance of the risk with clear legal documentation on his part will make him feel more comfortable riding the line between dosage reduction and treatment discontinuation.Bottom line:1.  Your anemia is related to the Rib (and perhaps a bit of the Peg).  You have fallen below 10 and a temporary dosage reduction of the Rib is appropriate while awaiting support with the Procrit (this takes 2-3 weeks to really see in the blood work).  A reduction in your Rib at this point may impact SVR, so the more time at optimal doses the beter.2.  Your platlet count is related to your Peg (either brand).  The Pegasys allows for a lower tolerance before FDA-advised dosage reduction, so a switch of brands may make your doc feel more comfortable about riding out a low platlet count. Go to Pegasys.com, click on for "healthcare professionals", go to pharmacokenetics, go down to see complete prescibing information, click "complete product info", and then on "Pegasys"...you can go to "dosage and administration" and see the FDA-approved chart for Pegasys.  Go to PegIntron.com and you can find the same info.  You and your doctor should discuss the comfort level with the platlets.  Many of us are letting them ride to 40-50 without getting too alarmed, as long as patients are aware of the risk of bleeding.GI.PA
